questions.question_text: An engineer added more APs to newly renovated areas in building. The engineer is now receiving Out-of-Sync alarms on Cisco Prime Infrastructure. Which two actions resolve this issue? (Choose two.)

choices.A: Manually synchronize from Cisco Prime Infrastructure.
choices.E: Add new APs to maps on Cisco Prime Infrastructure.
choices.C: Enable automatic synchronization on Cisco Prime Infrastructure.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AE
1. Manually synchronize from Cisco Prime Infrastructure: This ensures that the new APs are properly recognized and synchronized with the network.
2. Add new APs to maps on Cisco Prime Infrastructure: This ensures that the APs are correctly placed on the floor plans and maps, resolving any discrepancies.
The other options are incorrect or irrelevant:
B. Manually synchronize from MSE: MSE (Mobility Services Engine) is not directly responsible for resolving Out-of-Sync alarms related to APs.
C. Enable automatic synchronization on Cisco Prime Infrastructure: While this can help in the future, it does not immediately resolve the current issue.
D. Enable automatic synchronization on MSE: MSE is not involved in AP synchronization in this context.

Guys read it by your selfe and think:
Why should add an AP to the map Sync him, you add them from your inventory
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/net_mgmt/prime/infrastructure/3-5/user/guide/bk_CiscoPrimeInfrastructure_3_5_0_UserGuide/bk_CiscoPrimeInfrastructure_3_5_0_UserGuide_chapter_0100110.html#:~:text=NEs%20with%20MSE-,Set%20Up%20Synchronization%20Between%20MSE%20Databases%20and%20Product%20Database,-Manual%20synchronization%20of

Selected Answer: CE
Automatic looks smarter option here.

Manually synchronize from Cisco Prime Infrastructure.
Add new APs to maps on Cisco Prime Infrastructure.

Selected Answer: AC
A. This would immediately sync the system and then C. would keep it in sync going forward when future changes happen. I think E. is wrong because the APs have already been added to the map which is why there is an out of sync with MSE to begin with.

comments.content: I agree with this logic regarding AC
also would be A and E but E is one of the answer. The otra would be A or C
When you add more APs you need to add it to the maps on Prime. So E and C are correct.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CE
1. Add new APs to maps on Cisco Prime Infrastructure.
2. Enable automatic synchronization on Cisco Prime Infrastructure.

Prime 3.10 Testsystem:
Administration / Dashboards / Job Dashboard / System Jobs / Mobility Service Synchronization (this job must be scheduled)

Selected Answer: AE
Manual synchronization of Prime Infrastructure and MSE databases provides immediate synchronization. 
To prevent out-of-sync conditions, use Prime Infrastructure to carry out synchronization.

I reckon C,E are the best answer...although Manually syncing from PI is also an option.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/mse/7-6/MSE_CAS/7_6_MSE_CAS/7_4_MSE_CAS_chapter_011.pdf

Selected Answer: BD
I think B, D is correct
ref: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/net_mgmt/prime/infrastructure/3-5/user/guide/bk_CiscoPrimeInfrastructure_3_5_0_UserGuide/bk_CiscoPrimeInfrastructure_3_5_0_UserGuide_chapter_0100110.html#con_1301578:~:text=NEs%20with%20MSE-,Set%20Up%20Synchronization%20Between%20MSE%20Databases%20and%20Product%20Database,-Manual%20synchronization%20of

Selected Answer: D
I'm going to go with D here. The checkbox to enable local profiling is called Device Classification.

Source: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/wireless/catalyst-9800-series-wireless-controllers/215661-in-depth-look-into-client-profiling-on-9.html and logging into my own 9800.

Selected Answer: D
Device Classification:

Device classification is a feature on the Cisco Catalyst 9800 WLC that allows the controller to identify and classify connected devices based on their characteristics, such as operating system, device type, and behavior.

This feature does not require any external servers and uses built-in logic to classify devices.

Why Not the Other Options?:

A. Native Profile:
Native profiles are used for specific device configurations (e.g., Apple devices) but do not provide a comprehensive assessment of all client types.

B. MAC Classification:
MAC classification is used to identify devices based on their MAC addresses, but it does not provide detailed information about the device type or operating system.

C. Local Profile:
Local profiles are used for local authentication and profiling but require additional configuration and do not inherently classify devices.

Selected Answer: D
WLC 9800: Configuration --> Wireless --> Wireless Global
The checkbox to enable local profiling is called Device Classification.
In order for Local profiling to work, simply enable Device Classification under Configuration > Wireless > Wireless Global. This option enables MAC OUI, HTTP and DHCP profiling at the same time:

Selected Answer: D
answer is D
I think Spineraptor is right, in C9800 the checkbox called Device Classification.

questions.question_text:
A wireless administrator must assess the different client types connected to Cisco Catalyst 9800 Series Wireless Controller without using any external servers.
Which configuration must be added to the controller to achieve this assessment?

A customer is concerned that their wireless network is detecting spurious threats from channels that are not being used by their wireless infrastructure. Which two technologies must they deploy? (Choose two.)

comments.content:
B. Monitor Mode

Monitor mode APs do not serve clients but instead continuously scan all Wi-Fi channels for threats, rogue APs, and interference.
This helps detect real threats while filtering out irrelevant noise from unused channels.
D. Local Mode with WIPS Submode

APs in Local Mode serve clients, but when WIPS submode is enabled, they periodically scan the environment for security threats.
This balances client connectivity and threat detection without excessive false alarms.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
E. Rogue Detector Mode

Rogue detector APs do not use radios to scan the air.
They rely on wired network monitoring to detect rogue APs.
This does not help filter out spurious wireless threats from unused channels.
Conclusion:
To reduce false alarms and improve wireless threat detection, the customer should deploy Monitor Mode APs and Local Mode APs with WIPS Submode enabled.

comments.content:
Why Not the Other Options?
A. FlexConnect Mode:
FlexConnect Mode is used for branch office deployments and does not provide threat detection capabilities.

C. Sniffer Mode with No Submode:
Sniffer Mode is used for packet capture and analysis, not for continuous threat detection across all channels.

D. Local Mode with WIPS Submode:
While WIPS (Wireless Intrusion Prevention System) provides threat detection, it is typically limited to the channels used by the wireless infrastructure. It does not actively monitor unused channels unless combined with Monitor Mode

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BE
Monitor Mode:

In Monitor Mode, an access point (AP) scans all available channels to detect wireless activity, including threats such as rogue devices, interference, and attacks.

This mode allows the AP to monitor channels that are not actively used by the wireless infrastructure, ensuring comprehensive threat detection.

Rogue Detector Mode:

In Rogue Detector Mode, an AP is dedicated to detecting and identifying rogue devices on the network.

This mode works in conjunction with other APs in Monitor Mode to provide a complete picture of wireless threats, including those on unused channels.

.

Selected Answer: BD
Rogue Detector—In this mode, the AP radio is turned off, and the AP listens to wired traffic only. The controller passes the APs configured as rogue detectors as well as lists of suspected rogue clients and AP MAC addresses. The rogue detector listens for ARP packets only, and can be connected to all broadcast domains through a trunk link if desired.

Its one of those questions that is poorly worded. 
B. is wrong as WIPS sub mode is not listed
C. refers to MESH APs
D. is correct "In Enhanced Local mode (ELM), also called Local-WIPS mode, the AP still performs
client data servicing, but when scanning off-channel, the radio dwells on the channel
for an extended period of time, allowing enhanced attack detection. If you deploy
WIPS on some APs, you should prefer ELM to Local mode."
E. By process of elimination

The customer should deploy monitor mode (B) to passively capture and analyze wireless traffic on all channels, including those not being used by their wireless infrastructure. This will help them identify any spurious threats.

They should also deploy local mode with WIPS (Wireless Intrusion Prevention System) submode (D) to actively detect and prevent unauthorized wireless devices or threats in their wireless network.

These two technologies, monitor mode and local mode with WIPS submode, will help the customer effectively detect and mitigate spurious threats from channels that are not being used by their wireless infrastructure.

Selected Answer: BD
I agree with B. and D.

Selected Answer: DE
D and E, as stated by cvndani

I'd say the provided answer is correct BD.

The AP in rogue detector mode would not scan channels:

Rogue Detector Access Point
Rogue Detector—In this mode, the AP radio is turned off, and the AP listens to wired traffic only. The controller passes the APs configured as rogue detectors as well as lists of suspected rogue clients and AP MAC addresses. The rogue detector listens for ARP packets only, and can be connected to all broadcast domains through a trunk link if desired.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/wireless-mobility/wireless-lan-wlan/70987-rogue-detect.html

comments.content:
D is wrong

Rogue Detector Access Point
Rogue Detector—In this mode, the AP radio is turned off, and the AP listens to wired traffic only. The controller passes the APs configured as rogue detectors as well as lists of suspected rogue clients and AP MAC addresses. The rogue detector listens for ARP packets only, and can be connected to all broadcast domains through a trunk link if desired.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
I would say D and E.
Monitor mode would be the best option but then you would need to enable the WIPS submode (and that is not specified here). So the 2nd best option defined here would be "local mode with WIPS submode"

See a snippet of the cert guide

In Monitor mode with WIPS, the AP is fully dedicated to attack detection and miti-
gation. This is, of course, the most efficient mode, but the AP does not provide cli-
ent data service anymore. Note that your AP can be in regular Monitor mode (with
“None” as submode) and then only perform RRM-focused monitoring. You need to set
the monitor AP to WIPS submode in order to make it a full-time WIPS AP.

And then E is the only logical second answer.

Selected Answer: BD
I would say this is correct. 

AP in rogue detector mode turns off the radio and only listens to wired traffic and the question is mentioning wireless channels.

Selected Answer: DE
The correct answers must be D - E

questions.question_text: A network engineer created a new wireless network that will be used for guest access. The corporate network must utilize all rates. The guest network must use only lower rates instead of 802.11n data rates. To what must the WMM policy of the WLAN be set to accomplish this task?

discussion.content:
Agree with wirelessvibes.
Based on https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/wireless-mobility/voice-over-wireless-lan-vowlan/116056-technote-qos-00.html 

WMM also shortens the Interframe Spacing requirements for high priority packets so that voice and video can be sent in bursts without the need to wait as much for lower priority data inbetween. Additionally, WMM is needed in order to obtain 802.11n and 802.11ac data rates. This means that with --== WMM disabled ==-- or for non-WMM clients, the maximum usable data rate is 54 Mbps.

WMM
Enable WMM on a WLAN in order to create the simplest implementation of QoS; this option is on the QoS tab in the WLAN configuration menu. Other WMM policy settings are:

Disabled - WMM is not in use on the WLAN.
Required - Clients must support WMM or they are not permitted to access the WLAN.
Allowed - Clients that support WMM may use it, while those that do not support WMM can still connect to the network.
What you can do is go to your WLAN SSID and under the QoS feature, disable WMM. WMM is required for 802.11N support... Test is out and hopefully that solves your issue.

Selected Answer: C
The following are WMM policies available on the WLAN:
 - Disabled: Disables WMM on the WLAN.
 - Required: Requires client devices to use WMM. Devices that do not support WMM cannot join the WLAN.
 - Allowed: Devices that cannot support WMM can join the WLAN but will not benefit from the 802.11n rates.

From the above, it seems only WMM capable devices would be able to use 802.11n data rates. Therefore, if WMM is disabled, no device will be able to use 802.11n rates at all.
Correct answer is C.

Selected Answer: B
WMM also shortens the Interframe Spacing requirements for high priority packets so that voice and video can be sent in bursts without the need to wait as much for lower priority data inbetween. Additionally, WMM is needed in order to obtain 802.11n and 802.11ac data rates. This means that with WMM disabled or for non-WMM clients, the maximum usable data rate is 54 Mbps.

WMM
Enable WMM on a WLAN in order to create the simplest implementation of QoS; this option is on the QoS tab in the WLAN configuration menu. Other WMM policy settings are:

Disabled - WMM is not in use on the WLAN.
Required - Clients must support WMM or they are not permitted to access the WLAN.
Allowed - Clients that support WMM may use it, while those that do not support WMM can still connect to the network.

Selected Answer: C
C as it is about disabling the rates for guest access. Source by wirelessvibes is correct
Mandatory, so the correct answer are D

comments.content: I agree with C, you manage the WLC using the management IP.

discussion.content: Shouldnt the correct answer be C? You dont manage the WLC using the virtual interface ip

The answer is A we can configure WLC with virtual interface also. 

Configure the management interface:
interface management
ip address <management_ip_address> <subnet_mask>

Configure the virtual interface:
interface virtual <virtual_interface_number>
ip address <virtual_ip_address> <subnet_mask>

Enable management on the virtual interface:
management-interface virtual <virtual_interface_number>

Permit statements must be added to the top of the ACL in both directions, not just in one direction. This is because the controller needs to communicate with the network and vice versa for management purposes. Simply adding permit statements to the top of the ACL without specifying the network to be managed from and the virtual interface of the controller may not be sufficient to enable management again.

Selected Answer: C
Managment: via management interface with ROUTABLE IP
LWA: via virtual interface and this has a NON ROUTABLE IP.
Therefore A is wrong....

Selected Answer: C
CCNP Enterprise ENWLSD 300-425 ENWLSI 300-430 Official Cert Guide.pdf
Page 454
For AireOS controllers using versions 6.0 and later, CPU ACLs are applicable for traffic
originating both to and from the controller. Thus, when you’re creating the ACLs and
attaching them to the CPU, the ACL direction fields do not have any relevance.

Page 79
As with CAPWAP, the controller’s management interface is used to communicate with AAA
servers, as well as a host of other services, including MSE/CMX, directory servers, other
controllers, and more.

--> we need an ACL without direction, which includes the management interface and the admin network.

Selected Answer: C
It is C
provided answer is incorrect, i tested above deny acl in my simulation virtual wlc lab.
provided answer is correct, i tested above deny acl in my simulation virtual wlc lab.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer implemented the CPU ACL on your Cisco 5520 Series Wireless LAN Controller, and the controller is no longer manageable via the network. What must be changes on this CPU ACL to enable it to manage the controller again?

choices.D: Line 1 must be set to the inbound direction.
choices.A: Permit statements must be added to the top of the ACL in both directions, which specify the network to be managed from and the virtual interface of the controller.
choices.C: Permit statements must be added to the top of the ACL, which specify the network to be managed from.
choices.B: Line 1 must be set to a destination port of HTTP.
